title: Communication and Social Networks
section: Why do people form relationships / edges?
text:
Why do people form relationships / edges?

Psychological explanations
Strategic explanations
Exposure explanations

title: Communication and Social Networks
section: We are comfortable with people like us
text:
We are comfortable with people like us

Homophily

People who are like each other are more likely to become friends

title: Communication and Social Networks
section: We want our relationships to be in balance
text:
We want our relationships to be in balance

Balance theory

The enemy of my enemy is my friend
The friend of my enemy is my enemy










Balance theory is a bit more complicated. It says that we want our relationships to be in balance If A is friends with B and B is friends with C, but A and C are enemies, then balance theory says that this is unstable. Ties will dissolve or change valence.
This does depend on the type of relationship, though. What if black represents “hates”? If A hates B and B hates C, then maybe A will like C. Or if A is in love with B and B is in love with C, then A may hate C. These triangles are the source of lots of literature!

title: Communication and Social Networks
section: We want to be in relationships that help us
text:
We want to be in relationships that help us

Social exchange theory

Do the benefits of relationship outweigh the costs?
What resources does each node have and need?

Social capital

People seek to make relationships with powerful others
People seek to obtain powerful positions in the network

title: Communication and Social Networks
section: We become friends with our friends’ friends
text:
We become friends with our friends’ friends

Triadic closure / transitivity









It is worth nothing that homophily is another explanation for the ubiquity of triadic closure. Those who are like us are likely to be our friends; those who are like our friends are likely to be like us.

title: Communication and Social Networks
text:
Focus of Activity

Partially a pushback against other explanations

People choose or are forced into foci (clubs, neighborhoods, classes, etc.)
Ties are often a function of activities, not dyadic choices

title: Communication and Social Networks
section: Social networks are much more interesting!
text:
Social networks are much more interesting!


How do groups make decisions?
How do fads and fashions and misinformation and diseases spread?
How do our connections influence our perceptions about and behavior in the world?

Goals

Understand the foundations of network theory and analysis
Critically read social network studies
Learn how social networks relate to your own interests
Gain a basic understanding of gathering and analyzing network data in R

title: Communication and Social Networks
text:
Grading

I’m interested in teaching, not assessing
Goal is to build structures that encourage learning and accountability
Assignments will be turned in on Brightspace and/or discussed in class
I will provide general feedback
3 times during the semester you will turn in reflection pieces
If I disagree I will reach out

create_notable('zachary') %>%
  activate(nodes) %>%
  mutate(group = as.factor(group_infomap())) %>%
  ggraph(layout = 'kk') +
  geom_edge_fan(width=.2) + 
  geom_node_point(aes(color = group), size = 5)

title: Networks in small groups
text:
It depends on the task!


Centralization is beneficial for simple tasks
Decentralization is beneficial for complex tasks or when information is scattered
Rings are pretty bad no matter what :)

title: Networks in small groups
section: Communication isn’t usually determined from on high
text:
Communication isn’t usually determined from on high


Communication networks both represent and enable patterns of communication

title: Networks in small groups
section: Why do edges exist in small groups?
text:
Why do edges exist in small groups?


Social capital
Social exchange
Collective action
Transactive memory

Know who knows what
Knowledge is passed through communication

title: Networks in small groups
section: In general, “integrative” groups perform better at complex tasks
text:
In general, “integrative” groups perform better at complex tasks


Low hierarchy
Small periphery




In these groups, people are:

Coordinated
Motivated

title: Networks in small groups
text:
Groups are embedded


Work group vs. school assignment, etc.
People are also embedded in different groups
Tricky but important to consider the influence of environment
